Sekolah bagi Pelajar Pecandu Narkotik
07 Nov 2019, 00:11 by Muhammad Hatta
Muhammad Hatta Staf Dokter Balai Rehabilitasi BNN Baddoka, Makassar
Peredaran dan penyalahgunaan narkotik di kalangan pelajar kita semakin menakutkan. Penemuan ganja dengan jumlah fantastis (38 kilogram) dari tangan dua pelajar sekolah menengah di Depok, Jawa Barat, merupakan bukti terbaru. Ini menegaskan survei Badan Narkotika Nasional (BNN) pada 2018, yang mengungkap prevalensi narkotik pada kelompok pelajar dan mahasiswa pada angka 3,21 persen, jauh di atas angka prevalensi nasional (2,1 persen). BNN memperkirakan 5,9 juta pelajar kita telah menjadi penyalah guna aktif.
Tak mengherankan jika peringatan hari anti-narkotik internasional tahun ini mengambil tema yang berfokus pada komponen utama gerbong bonus demografi yang diprediksi beringsut mulai 2020. Namun fokus pada "hulu" permasalahan (via interdiksi) akan sia-sia tanpa penanganan komprehensif di "hilir" (rehabilitasi pelajar penyalah guna).
Undang-Undang Nomor 35 Tahun 2014 tentang Perlindungan Anak menyebutkan bahwa bentuk perlindungan khusus yang diberikan kepada penyalah guna anak adalah pengawasan, pencegahan, perawatan, dan rehabilitasi. Rehabilitasi yang dimaksudkan adalah proses terapi yang bersifat holistik, komprehensif, dan tak menyalahi hak dasar anak. Sayangnya, belum ada pusat rehabilitasi yang mampu memenuhi kriteria tersebut dan diperburuk dengan stigma terhadap mereka (Ombudsman, 2018). Kasus dikeluarkannya tiga pelajar sekolah menengah pertama di Mimika, Papua Barat, merupakan bukti masih kentalnya stigma sekolah terhadap pelajar penyalah guna.
Saat ini, mayoritas pusat rehabilitasi rawat inap di Indonesia menerapkan metode komunitas terapi (therapeutic community), yaitu pendekatan psikoterapi yang mensyaratkan pesertanya berdiam dan beraktivitas di suatu area terkontrol selama tiga hingga enam bulan. Ini dilakukan agar mereka dapat saling berinteraksi dan tolong-menolong selaku kelompok menuju pemulihan yang sempurna (Dye et al, 2009). Metode ini dinilai tak sesuai lagi bagi populasi usia sekolah karena menghilangkan hak anak untuk berkembang di dunia sosial secara normal. Selain itu, metode ini bertentangan dengan program wajib belajar karena mereka "diistirahatkan" dari proses pendidikan formal (KPAI, 2019).
Ironisnya, celah menganga tersebut luput dari perhatian pemerintah selama ini. Penerapan kurikulum berbasis P4GN, yang merupakan poin utama Nota Kesepahaman Kementerian Pendidikan dengan BNN yang diteken pada 2018, hanya menekankan aspek pencegahan dan demand reduction, belum menjangkau metode pendidikan pelajar yang tengah direhabilitasi. Komisi Perlindungan Anak Indonesia (KPAI) pun mendesak dibentuknya rehabilitasi terpadu dan holistik serta tanpa menghilangkan hak anak untuk melanjutkan pendidikannya.
Bermula pada 1979, Sekolah Pemulihan adalah program rehabilitasi anak dan remaja pada suatu fasilitas sehingga mereka tetap dapat bersekolah seperti pelajar lainnya. Sekolah ini telah menjadi standar penanganan pelajar pecandu di Amerika Serikat, sehingga tercatat ada puluhan sekolah jenis ini yang tersebar di 15 negara bagian (ARS, 2019). Jumlah siswanya tak banyak (25-50 orang) karena sekolah ini menerapkan integrated boarding school agar mereka dimonitor secara berkala.
Sayangnya, biaya operasional yang tinggi dan ketersediaan sumber daya manusia (konselor, psikolog, dan tenaga medis) menyebabkan model sekolah ini hanya dapat dilaksanakan di negara-negara maju (Faggiano et al, 2014). Untuk negara dengan sumber daya terbatas seperti Indonesia, Sekolah Pemulihan dapat diefektifkan via penerapan pada pusat-pusat rehabilitasi narkotik yang telah ada dan diintegrasikan ke dalam program-program di tempat tersebut (Karakos, 2014). Modifikasi tersebut dikenal sebagai Sekolah Pemulihan Berbasis Institusi (SPBI).
Idealnya, SPBI memiliki guru-guru pengampu mata pelajaran sesuai dengan tingkat pengetahuan siswa yang tengah direhabilitasi. Namun lebarnya variasi tingkat pendidikan siswa yang tengah direhabilitasi akan berdampak pada besarnya anggaran. Sebuah penelitian di Yogyakarta memperkirakan biaya minimal dalam mendidik seorang siswa sekolah dasar dengan metode tersebut adalah Rp 246 ribu per bulan (Zamroni et al, 2012).
Konsep SPBI berfokus pada solusi digital via aplikasi belajar mandiri, seperti Ruang Guru dan Ruang Belajar milik Kementerian Pendidikan. Pada jam pelajaran sekolah, mereka masuk ke ruang tersebut dan belajar secara mandiri sesuai dengan aras pendidikannya. Selepas belajar, mereka kembali melanjutkan program terapi rehabilitasi adiksi. Karena siswa tetap dapat belajar serta pihak sekolah dan keluarga dilibatkan dalam proses ini, SPBI dinilai lebih efektif ketimbang terapi rehabilitasi konvensional lainnya.
Konsep SPBI yang rencananya berlokasi di enam balai rehabilitasi milik BNN tak akan dapat berjalan optimal tanpa dukungan institusi terkait lainnya, seperti Kementerian Pendidikan, Kementerian Kesehatan, dan Kementerian Sosial. Koordinasi tersebut menemukan momentum saat ini dengan bakal direvisinya Undang-Undang Narkotika oleh Dewan Perwakilan Rakyat. Sudah saatnya pemerintah bergerak cepat menyelamatkan populasi pelajar dari ancaman narkotik agar tak menggerus bonus demografi kita nanti.

School for Narcotics Addict Students
Nov 7 2019, 00:11 by Muhammad Hatta
Muhammad Hatta Staff Doctor of the Rehabilitation Center of BNN Baddoka, Makassar
Circulation and abuse of narcotics among our students is increasingly frightening. The discovery of a fantastic amount of cannabis (38 kilograms) from the hands of two high school students in Depok, West Java, is the latest evidence. This confirms the National Narcotics Agency (BNN) survey in 2018, which revealed the prevalence of narcotics among groups of students at 3.21 percent, far above the national prevalence rate (2.1 percent). BNN estimates that 5.9 million of our students have become active abusers.
Not surprisingly, the commemoration of the international anti-narcotics day this year takes a theme that focuses on the main components of the demographic bonus carriage which is predicted to inch from 2020. But the focus on "upstream" problems (via interdiction) will be in vain without comprehensive handling in the "downstream" ( rehabilitation of abuser students).
Law Number 35 of 2014 concerning Child Protection states that the specific forms of protection provided to child abusers are supervision, prevention, care and rehabilitation. Rehabilitation is intended as a process of therapy that is holistic, comprehensive, and does not violate the basic rights of children. Unfortunately, there is no rehabilitation center that is able to meet these criteria and is exacerbated by the stigma against them (Ombudsman, 2018). The case of the issuance of three junior high school students in Mimika, West Papua, is evidence of the continued stigma of the school against students of abuse.
At present, the majority of inpatient rehabilitation centers in Indonesia apply the therapeutic community method, which is a psychotherapy approach that requires participants to stay and be active in a controlled area for three to six months. This is done so that they can interact with each other and help as a group towards complete recovery (Dye et al, 2009). This method is considered inappropriate for the school-age population because it eliminates the child's right to develop normally in the social world. In addition, this method is contrary to compulsory education programs because they are "rested" from the formal education process (KPAI, 2019).
Ironically, the gaping gap has escaped the government's attention so far. The application of the P4GN-based curriculum, which is the main point of the Ministry of Education's Memorandum of Understanding with BNN signed in 2018, only emphasizes the aspects of prevention and demand reduction, not yet reaching the educational methods of students being rehabilitated. The Indonesian Child Protection Commission (KPAI) also urges the establishment of integrated and holistic rehabilitation and without eliminating the right of children to continue their education.
Starting in 1979, the Recovery School is a rehabilitation program for children and young people in a facility so that they can still go to school like other students. This school has become the standard for handling addicted students in the United States, so there are dozens of schools of this type that are spread across 15 states (ARS, 2019). There are not many students (25-50 people) because this school implements an integrated boarding school so that they are monitored regularly.
Unfortunately, high operational costs and the availability of human resources (counselors, psychologists, and medical personnel) cause this school model can only be implemented in developed countries (Faggiano et al, 2014). For countries with limited resources such as Indonesia, the School of Recovery can be made effective via application to existing narcotics rehabilitation centers and integrated into the programs at the site (Karakos, 2014). This modification is known as the Institution-Based Recovery School (SPBI).
Ideally, the SPBI has subject matter teachers in accordance with the level of knowledge of the students being rehabilitated. However, the wide variation in the level of education of students being rehabilitated will have an impact on the size of the budget. A study in Yogyakarta estimated that the minimum cost of educating an elementary school student with this method was Rp 246 thousand per month (Zamroni et al, 2012).
The SPBI concept focuses on digital solutions via self-study applications, such as the Ministry of Education's Teacher's Room and Study Room. During school hours, they enter the room and study independently according to their educational level. After learning, they resumed their addiction rehabilitation therapy program. Because students can still learn and the school and family are involved in this process, SPBI is considered more effective than other conventional rehabilitation therapies.
The SPBI concept which is planned to be located in six rehabilitation centers owned by BNN will not be able to run optimally without the support of other relevant institutions, such as the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Health, and the Ministry of Social Affairs. The coordination is finding momentum now with the revision of the Narcotics Act by the House of Representatives. It is time for the government to move quickly to save the student population from the threat of narcotics so as not to erode our demographic bonus later.
